title: Noscapine effective in PC
abstract: Noscapine treatment of 300mg/Kg/d administered to PC 3 human prostate cancer-bearing immunodeficient mice revealed a significant reduction of tumor volume and a tumor inhibition rate of 60% with no identifiable toxicity. Treatment resulted in a slow incid
citation: 17th Intl Prostate Ca Update Mtg, Vail, Col;Feb 15, 2007.

title: Evidence of a mechanism by which etanercept increased TNF-alpha in multiple myeloma: new insights into the biology of TNF-alpha giving new treatment opportunities--the role of bupropion.

title: Clinical influence of imuthiol (sodium ditiocarb) in HIV-infected patients: a review of 4 controlled studies and long-term influence.
abstract: Between November 1983 and December 1988, more than 2,100 HIV-infected patients have been enrolled in double-blind, placebo controlled studies of Imuthiol (sodium ditiocarb, DTC). To date, results from three controlled studies in 170 ARC patients are avail
citation: Int Conf AIDS. 1989 Jun 4-9; 5: 402 (abstract no. W.B.P.301).

citation: http://www.freepatentsonline.com/5206264.html

title: Antidepressants and antiepileptic drugs for chronic non-cancer pain.
abstract: The development of newer classes of antidepressants and second-generation antiepileptic drugs has created unprecedented opportunities for the treatment of chronic pain. These drugs modulate pain transmission by interacting with specific neurotransmitters
citation: Am Fam Physician. 2005 Feb 1;71(3):483-90.

title: Cardiac glycosides stimulate Ca2+ increases and apoptosis in androgen-independent, metastatic human prostate adenocarcinoma cells.
abstract: Cardiac glycosides are used clinically to increase contractile force in patients with cardiac disorders. Their mechanism of action is well established and involves inhibition of the plasma membrane Na+/K+-ATPase, leading to alterations in intracellular K+
citation: McConkey DJ, Lin Y, Nutt LK, Ozel HZ, Newman RA.  Cardiac glycosides stimulate Ca2+ increases and apoptosis in androgen-independent, metastatic human prostate adenocarcinoma cells. Cancer Res. 2000 Jul 15;60(14):3807-12.

title: Neuroprotection by minocycline facilitates significant recovery from spinal cord injury in mice.
abstract: Acute spinal cord injury (SCI) produces tissue damage that continues to evolve days and weeks after the initial insult, with corresponding functional impairments. Reducing the extent of progressive tissue loss ('neuroprotection') following SCI should resu
citation: Wells JE, Hurlbert RJ, Fehlings MG, Yong VW. Neuroprotection by minocycline facilitates significant recovery from spinal cord injury in mice. Brain. 2003 Jul;126(Pt 7):1628-37.

title: The determination of additive effect and intraocular pressure lowering effects of 0.05% bromocriptine and 0.25% timolol.
abstract: It has been confirmed that topically applied bromocriptine has a satisfactory intraocular pressure (IOP) lowering effect without serious ocular or systemic side effects. We compared the IOP lowering effects of 0.05% bromocriptine and 0.25% timolol and det
citation: Elibol O, Güler C, Arici K, Topalkara A, Demircan S. The determination of additive effect and intraocular pressure lowering effects of 0.05% bromocriptine and 0.25% timolol. Int Ophthalmol. 1996-1997;20(1-3):53-5.

title: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome and bromocriptine
abstract: Bromocriptine used to treat neuroleptic malignant syndrome: PO or by NG tube starting with 2.5 mg tid and increasing q 24 h by 2.5 mg tid until a response is seen or until a max dose of 60 mg is achieved.
citation: Canadian Movement Disorder Group, Neuroleptic malignant syndrome, http://www.cmdg.org/Movement_/drug/Neuroleptic_Malignant_Syndrome/neuroleptic_malignant_syndrome.htm

title: Bromocriptine reduces lipid peroxidation and enhances spatial learning and hippocampal neuron survival in a rodent model of focal brain trauma.
abstract: Oxidative stress is a significant contributor to the secondary sequelae of traumatic brain injury (TBI), and may mediate subsequent neurobehavioral deficits and histopathology. The present study examined the neuroprotective effects of bromocriptine (BRO),
citation: Kline AE, Massucci JL, Ma X, Zafonte RD, Dixon CE. Bromocriptine reduces lipid peroxidation and enhances spatial learning and hippocampal neuron survival in a rodent model of focal brain trauma. J Neurotrauma. 2004 Dec;21(12):1712-22.

citation: Damian Carragher, Louise Hartson, Javier Rangel-Moreno and Troy D. Randall. Low dose oral interferon-α reduces morbidity and promotes recovery from influenza infection. Trudeau Institute, Saranac Lake, NY.

title: Angiotensin converting enzyme inhibition prevents development of muscle and nerve dysfunction and stimulates angiogenesis in streptozotocin-diabetic rats.
abstract: The effects of the angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor lisinopril on slow and fast twitch muscle contractile properties, nerve conduction and hypoxic resistance, and muscle and nerve capillary density were examined in streptozotocin-diabetic rats. Pro
citation: Cameron NE, Cotter MA, Robertson S.Angiotensin converting enzyme inhibition prevents development of muscle and nerve dysfunction and stimulates angiogenesis in streptozotocin-diabetic rats. Diabetologia. 1992 Jan;35(1):12-8.

title: Preventive and therapeutic effects of gliclazide on diabetic retinopathy: comparison with glibenclamide treatment.
abstract: The effects of long-term treatment with gliclazide on diabetic retinopathy and platelet adhesion were investigated. The subjects comprised 25 patients with NIDDM, of which 12 cases and 13 cases were treated with gliclazide and glibenclamide respectively.
citation: Minami N, Ikeda Y, Abe M.Preventive and therapeutic effects of gliclazide on diabetic retinopathy: comparison with glibenclamide treatment.Tohoku J Exp Med. 1983 Dec;141 Suppl:707-11.
